rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co. This episode is brought to
you by Neon. For the first time in our
industry, developers can finally have
their own DTOC channels to save on app
store fees and build closer
relationships with players. But there's
a catch. Selling direct means either
building complex infrastructure yourself
or choosing among legacy providers whose
inexperience in games or questionable
reputations pose real risk to your
business. Luckily, there's Neon, the
DTOC platform built for games. As a
merchant of record with customizable web
shops optimized for conversion and
modern APIs that let you use your
existing live ops tools, Neon is trusted
by some of the biggest names in gaming
to help you sell direct without the
typical overhead. To start selling
direct and finally take control over
your full player experience, simply head
to
neonpay.com or check out the link in the
show notes. This episode is brought to
you by Leveler, the Discord community
intelligence platform helping game
studios cut through the noise. With
powerful social listening and sentiment
analysis, Leveler tracks millions of
Discord messages to tell you exactly
what your players care about. No more
guesswork, just realtime insights into
what's working, what's not, and what
your community wants next. To learn more
about how Leveler can help your team
unlock immense value from Discord,
simply visit leveler.com or check out
the link in the show notes. And with
that, let's jump into the episode. All
right, what's up everyone and welcome to
the Navic Gaming Podcast. I'm your host,
Alex, and this is the interview and
insight segment. As we always do at
Navic, we're looking to cover the
juggernauts of gaming, PC, console,
mobile, AAA, ad networks, but also the
pockets of games that don't have a light
shine on them too often or might be
emerging, meaning that the market isn't
fully mature or has room to grow. In my
last show, we covered the global growth
of China, venturing into publishing into
the West, and the production of
highfidelity AAA games like Blackmouth
Wukong. And today, we're going to set
our sights on another continent where
games are experiencing massive growth,
albeit in a smaller market. We're
talking about the Africa gaming market
today, which amounted to 1.8 million
last year, growing 12.4% year-over-year,
defying the global average of 2%. The
number of African gamers rose to about
350 million, a 10% growth rate. But in
breaking down this market, we're not
going to take these numbers just at face
value, but really discuss what the
opportunity in this market is from a
consumer perspective and from a
development perspective. What is hard
about this market? and what are some of
the things that have to go right for it
to become a gaming hub. And so I'm
really excited to be hosting the
conversation today with two guests who
live and breathe this market, but from
different vantage points, which I hope
will give us some color on the roles
that the startup side and both AAA are
playing in propelling the space forward.
My first guest is Cordell Robin Coker,
co-founder and CEO of Cary First, a
mobile games publisher located in Cape
Town, South Africa, I believe. Um, this
is actually Carrie First's second
appearance on our show as Lucy, one of
the other co-founders, I think, appeared
on our show quite some time ago. So,
welcome Cordell. Thank you for having
me. Exciting. Um, and my next guest is
Tammy Aphalabi, who is leading Xbox
global expansion for Africa and the
Middle East. Tam of course will share
his own story, but I will succinctly
call him an awakened consultant. Um,
using his strategic powers for good. Um,
and I'm very excited to have you both on
today. It'll be fascinating to discuss
uh the perspective of Africa from the
AAA seat. So, welcome Tammy. Thank you,
Alex. It's great to be here with you.
Hi, Cordell. Looking forward to chatting
with you guys.
Awesome. Um, all right. So, I know you
guys gave a talk together at HBS, so you
guys already know each other, but um,
with our standard course of things, I'd
love for you to share a little bit about
yourselves for our audience. Um, your
background, you know, who were you
before this? Um, Cordell, why did you
file Carrie first? Tammy, why'd you join
Xbox? Um, and as a bonus question, I
would love to know what your favorite
game is from the African gaming market.
And I guess how you classify that is up
to you. So, um, Cordell, why don't you
kick us off? All right, let's do it. So,
I'm uh originally from Sierra Leone in
West Africa. Left when I was about six
during a war in the '9s and uh and then
grew up in the States. I um went to
school sort of on the west coast and
then started my career in finance and
investing. So somewhat unusual for uh
someone in the gaming industry. I was
first an investor for about 7 years with
the Carlile group and had the
opportunity to move back to West Africa
with them and start investing in
businesses across the continent. Um,
that was a lot of fun, but ultimately I
decided that I wanted to kind of get in
the action myself. And uh, having always
been a big big gamer growing up before I
started working like 100hour weeks on
Wall Street, I thought that it would be
really really interesting to see if I
could build a a game company focused on
on Africa. Um, been lots of twists and
turns since which we can talk about, but
it's been a really interesting ride.
And your favorite game? Favorite game?
uh African game is Moncala Adventures. I
had to pick uh one of ours and it's
African because it's built by Carrie
First and uh actually it's built
originally by a twoperson studio in
Ethiopia called Kenna Games. Um but
since then we've we've been uh building
and publishing it. So Malaur. Yeah. Very
cool. Um I assume similar to Monala the
board game. Precisely. Okay. Very cool.
All right. Um, so you too are you're not
an enlightened consultant, you're an
enlightened uh you're an enlightened
banker.
All right, Tammy. Yeah. Um, I think, you
know, that's really interesting because
I think it speaks to um just how nent
the market is where a lot of us in this
market are sort of transplants from
other um industries. Um, but yeah, with
me, I think uh I was born in the UK, but
I was raised in Nigeria. Um, so I'm I
have two Nigerian parents. Um and then
you know being Nigerian in uni I got a
law degree because those are your
options law finance or be a doctor or
something. Um so after that I moved back
to Nigeria and I worked as a consultant
for a few years and then I moved to
finance. I've been all over the place
and I remember during the lockdown that
was sort of an inflection point for me
in terms of career and what I wanted to
do and I sort of casually hosted an
esports tournament with my brother which
turned out to be really big. He didn't
expect it to be but everyone was stuck
in the house so it became a thing and
then suddenly you know opportunities to
work in gaming as a career sort of
popped up as you know go leading on from
that and then I got the chance to work
at Xbox um in global expansion and here
we are. All right. And your favorite
game? Yes. My favorite game from Africa
currently um I'm going to pick a game
that's not out yet. Uh, it's called
Legends of Arishia, but you can see all
about it and hear the story just because
I'm really really interested in the law
and the African history, the cultural
history it brings. And it's based on a
culture that I personally am a part of
as well. So to see that on a global
platform that sort of, you know, shows
me where this could lead. Um, so I'm
very excited about that. Uh, I also
really like Angaferoot, which is from
um, Free Lives in South Africa. Um, I
played it recently and it's got a sort
of a kick pad that you can kick while
you play, which sounds really simple but
is extremely fun. Um, so yeah, those are
my favorite games from Africa right now.
Awesome. Yeah, and we'll definitely talk
a little bit about um I think that spec
that game specifically in our section um
about, you know, Africa as a development
hub. Um, but guys, it was great to hear
a little bit about both of your
backgrounds. um you know like you both
said you know from different industries
coming to gaming and would also love to
see how that informs your perspective on
an emerging market like Africa but um I
want to kick off our first topic right
and so Cordell when we did our kickoff
call you asked an interesting question
can Africa be the next China um and I
actually think that's a great way to
strategically kick off our discussion
today um as a founder of a mobile games
publisher in Africa you must certainly
believe there's a big future ahead for
this market Um, and so to we're going to
start with the consumer perspective, but
from your vantage point, what about
Africa now tracks with the prior
behaviors of the early premature Chinese
gaming market?
Yeah, I I definitely think it it can and
it really all starts with demographics
really just just people. So Africa has
one and a half billion people and it's
incredibly young. So median age of like
19. And so the the first thing is you
know folks are coming online and it is
similar to China and Southeast Asia a
mobile first market. And so people are
when they start gaming the first thing
that they engage with is mobile freeto
play. And so if you think about all of
the play patterns um that took off as
freeto play I would say really kind of
was born in Asia. um players on the
continent are are really really I would
say well adapted and engaged uh to those
and and you don't have that transition
from let's say a traditionally console
or PC market that that then is is
adapted I think the sim big similarities
highly highly social so you have some of
the highest rates of engagement on
social media um a lot of people's lives
are exist online and when you think
about sort of mobile, it really is the
center of people's lives when you think
about uh things like finance, mobility
um and sort of gaming and social is
really no different. So I I think there
are a lot of core similarities. I also
think there will need to be certain
adaptations in order to really crack the
market um in a similar way that that
you've had to see um regional publishers
in in China and and in Southeast Asia.
Tammy, any reactions to that in terms of
what's tracking and similar between the
early Chinese market and Africa? Um
yeah, I think you know the mobile
dominance is a big thing. Um, I think
the main difference that sticks out to
me is that China is pretty is
homogeneous the word I'm looking for? I
hope I'm not using the wrong word there.
Well, it's one country, one language,
whereas Africa might have the market
size, but then we have different
languages, different cultures, you have
different governments you need to work
through and things like that. But in
terms of young population, mobile
driven, um, free-to-play popularity and
very culturally strong themes. So
there's a lot of potential for like
localization and making things key for
each um unique to the individual
markets. So I I'm sort of hesitant to go
too far into the comparison because of
the big differences. Um I often think
about the African market as being
slightly more similar to Southeast Asia
for instance um in terms of where we are
because there's also a big technology
gap between China and Africa as of
present moment. I see. Yeah. And I think
that's where I was going to go with my
next question which was you know what
are the actual install bases like? Um
what is the console attach rate the PC
attach rate and the mobile attach rate
in Africa? And I'm sure it does vary by
country, but across the board, um, what
would you, if you had to say, what
percent of people own a PC, a console,
and a mobile device, what would that be?
Yeah. Yeah. Um, I think typically, and a
big thing about this market is data. So,
um, you know, in the last few months,
we've gotten um, Carrie First have done
one and Malia have done like reports as
well to sort of consolidate information.
Um so depending on who you ask you're
going to get the mobile numbers are
going to be in the 90% range. So
anywhere from 85 80 to 90% is mobile and
then you have um PC and console with
around the 15% range 10 to 15% range and
that feels very accurate in you know my
lived experience as well. So yeah I
think the data holds up there. So I'd
say it's a 85 to 90% um mobile market
and then PC and console sort of split
what's left. Okay. So that's the split
between the people who have the devices.
But what is the actual like penetration
rate of those devices across the actual
population? So in the for the continent
of Africa does 90% of them own a phone.
So on on a mobile so I guess smartphone
penetration which is the important thing
uh because you can't play games well fun
games you can play on future phones so
like phone penetration is over 100%
because you have a bunch of people who
have multiple devices um which is a
weird quirk of the market mobile penetr
or smartphone penetration is like 40ish%
I see um and uh so call it 600 million
people and then and then sort of the
percentage of those that are gaming is
then you know call it 350 to 400 million
folks.
Yeah. So that's how it shakes out which
is pretty interesting. It's growing as
you said double digits every year for
the last 10 to 15 years and um but it's
still really really early right. it's in
the it's in the first quartile or
whatever uh you want to sort of decide
to to choose. So yeah to some extent
it's also encouraging right because it's
you know it's a you like growth it's
very simple answer get more phones in
the hands of more people um and then
they will play more games uh and so I
think it's a different challenge for you
know what's happening in the west which
is just a huge utter you know I guess
concentration of content and then that
content fighting for attention um so
okay so we talked a little bit about the
console and PC attach rates um you know
obviously Tam as you said 80
95% mobile um what genres of mobile
games are actually being played
regularly if you had to break down the
market into that into percentages um you
know in the within the mobile gaming
market I mean okay that's a that's a
good question um I would say casual
games would be first uh in my opinion um
so that would be the main genre uh I'd
go sports maybe a close second so casual
games typically and again it depends on
who you're coding with these numbers,
but I see casual gaming range from the
30 to 40% range. Um, and that's
typically has it at first. Uh, you have
sports games typically soccer games, but
sports games typically come in second.
Um, and then you have, it varies, RPG,
shooters. Shooters are pretty um pretty
popular on the continent as well. I I
put those as the top three uh in my
experience. And I'd say I'd go 40, 35,
25 maybe. Okay. Um, and for those games,
I guess specifically, would you say that
they're those are games that are
internationally based that are being
played? Um, or are there local
storytelling elements or local games
that are in that in those top five to 10
games in Africa? No. No. It's typically
international games that have scaled
into Africa and are doing well. Um, you
know, we have the odd, and I'm sure
we'll get into African successes later
on, but you know, you have a game like
The President by Mean, which did very
well on the global market. Um, but
typically it's the other way around,
right? It's you have a Call of Duty,
League of Legends, um, Candy Crush, um,
FIFA. So, it's usually the, uh, major
global IPs, um, and the ones that have
mobile versions naturally can feed off
that and and continue to grow.
So yeah. Yeah, that's that's t typically
what we see as well. There's a little
bit of a divide depending on the country
and how and just the demographics. So
South Africa tends to be a little bit
more mature kind of similar spend and
maturity. Um even iOS to Android split
as like southern Europe. Um whereas if
you take the behemoths Nigeria which has
a couple hundred million people, Egypt
which has a hundred those are young kind
of
maledominated competitive uh geos and so
that's where you get your shooters your
RPGs your strategy games and then in
southern Africa is more like your your
puzzle your tabletop games and so on.
Um, interesting. And yeah, agreed. We
one of the original the things that we
were doing is is building original IP
for the African continent. And and we
learned pretty quickly that most the
biggest bigger challenge was that
Africans wanted to play the same games
as folks in the States. And how do we
make that accessible for them uh based
on certain challenges? There's honestly
one exception and uh it's a game called
Niger Ludo which is obviously a Ludo
game uh made by a single developer who I
think is uh is a government worker. We
reached out to him like 5 years ago. Um
one dude and it's just always at the top
of the charts and we have no idea why.
Um but he's cracked like some play
pattern or or social dynamic. I actually
have a I have a thesis. I think it's
local multiplayer basically to be able
to pair up with friends and play in the
same place. Um, but that's one of the
few exceptions. Uh, but typically it's
it's global games that are topping the
charts. Very interesting. Speaks to um
culture a lot as well because Ludo is a
really popular game to play with friends
and family here. It's um sort of a board
game. Do you guys know Luda? Do you
know, Alex? I have not played but I have
heard of the game. Yeah. Yeah. Okay. So
yeah, it's a board game, but you can
play online as well with friends, and
it's a lot of fun. Yeah. Um, and I think
that obviously I think it ties into a
lot of what can be done to localize
something to a very specific market.
What did you grow up playing? I grew up
playing perhaps Monopoly Go, sorry,
Monopoly and life. And I don't play
Monopoly Go now, but you know, one could
see that the market has that play
pattern. They're familiar with this game
and therefore it's easier to get into.
But um you know Cordell you said
something that's really interesting
about um actually what we really want to
do is just get global IP into the hands
of players right and that brings us to
kind of switching over from you know
what is actually opportunity on the
consumer side and what's exciting the
growth rate the low install base of
mobile phones um and smartphones that
could just simply grow but now more over
to the side of the the the challenges
right and when we we talked last year
you you pointed out three um and I want
to dive into each of those three
different challenges Um and I think I
believe if I recall from memory a lot of
that is around infrastructure payments
and go to market.
Yeah, absolutely. So the the first we we
would call technology and and there are
a couple layers to it. One is device. So
you know the the the gift of mobile is
you don't have to buy a $1,000 dedicated
gaming device in order to play. But the
curse is that the devices have a really
wide spectrum of capabilities. And so if
you think your iPhone 14 or 15, whatever
is the latest, um, versus which is
basically like a superco computer in
your phone is probably more powerful
than your laptop was 7 years ago. Um,
versus like a
$75 Chinese-made Android phone um, from
Techno or Infinix. like the processing,
battery life, the and the sort of
graphics are completely different. And
so one challenge is that you know when
you have games that are built in the
west in these environments where
bandwidth is essentially free, it's a
utility like turning on the tap um and
devices tend to be super powerful. you
tend to have games which are built in a
way that don't really work for a couple
billion people across Africa and and
honestly the global south. And so tech
from a device standpoint is is one
piece. And then the second is broader
connectivity particularly with like
competitive games where and that's kind
of easier to fix because it's just about
servers and having points of presence
that are closer to players on the
continent which is pretty rare for your
big game companies but is pretty easy to
do with cloud now. Interesting. um you
know doubling down before we move to
payments and some of the stuff around go
to market but you know it's you said
that it's one of the biggest problems
and um I'm curious from a gaming you're
a game publisher who are you relying on
to make this headwind you know go away
uh like you said it's easy to stand up
servers but like why has infrastructure
been challenging for so long if it's
easy to stand up servers
I would say with regard to that we're
dependent on on global
major global game companies to to
recognize that there is an emerging
player base and and to do the minimal
work required to to stand up servers. So
in in that situation, you know, you have
AWS, you have sort of Google Cloud, you
have Azure, um, across all the major
markets on the continent, and it's just
convincing, you know, your your your
major game companies that it's worth
doing. And so we've we've worked with a
couple companies like Activision,
um, and some others to set up servers,
but so I would say that's it's on them.
And then as far as like making games
that aren't 4 gigabytes on download and
don't require uh you know an incredible
computing, it again kind of sits with
with the game companies to to care
enough to to do so and to see that
opportunity. Tammy, are you hearing
that? That's a cry for help. Um
how do you respond?
Um, listen, I I mean I'll respond to the
extent that I can respond. I think I
agree that those are definitely
opportunities there. Um, I can say those
are conversations that, you know, we
have. Um, I'm not always a part of those
conversations, but I know that they
happen. Um, and it's something that I
personally would advocate for is because
I think also it's one thing to see that
this market has a lot of potential, but
I think there's an opportunity to be
proactive about creating the market,
right? I think we can project all this
opportunity, but if we really put the
effort into it, I think the opportunity
is even larger than we tend to see. Um,
so yeah, I mean that that's my response.
I think those are the same challenges we
see. So things around even around like
local currency payments like we're
having those conversations all the time
trying to solve for that and Africa is a
really big continent as well. It's quite
fragmented. So it's yeah there's several
steps to it but these are these are the
challenges that companies like ours are
looking into. All right. And you
mentioned payments. Um, and I want to
shift over because I think that's
another challenge that you've mentioned
a lot because the payment system is very
different from the west and potentially
diversified. But, um, from your guys'
perspective, what is the most common
like localized game pricing model in
Africa? And I mean that in the question
of how do people pay and what do they
typically find themselves paying for?
It's it's a really good question. So I
believe of the three challenges that
this is by far the most important
because it speaks it speaks to the unit
profitability of a player. And if a game
company thinks that they can make money
uh on a given cohort of players, they
will do the work with regard to uh tech
localization go to market in order to
serve them. And so to answer your
question directly today there are a
really fragmented range of payment
methods. So in any given country you
will have you know things like mobile
money which are wallets linked to
telecom companies. You'll have unique
local wallets like Venmo but with
different names. you will have direct
instant bank transfer which is much more
seamless in many of these countries like
Nigeria and South Africa than than the
US like much more um and you will have
different like offline to online
methods. So in North Africa you can go
to a post office or a grocery store and
give cash and top up a digital wallet.
So the cool thing is that the payment
methods are available. People use them
to buy stuff. they're ubiquitous. Um,
but the challenge is that if you want to
serve the 10 largest countries, you
probably need 80 different payment
methods in order to like have ubiquity
and and obviously that just looking at
at your eyes there.
Uh, meanwhile in the US, you're trying
to find like a merchant of record so you
do zero payments. Like you're just like
just have it go through Steam, you know,
like or just Stripe, Stripe, PayPal,
that's it. Um,
100%. Like we're in the west super
spoiled with with the ubiquity of cards
and like interoperability across every
country, every bank, every network. Um,
and so and so that's the challenge. So,
so folks have the appetite to make inapp
purchases and we've found that when you
make payments available for them for the
right IP that they monetize at
incredibly high rates. Um but you got to
bridge the gap.
And I guess how similar to my first
question of who are you relying on to do
that? Is that more of something that you
are trying to solve on the carry first
side or is there kind of like a large
wave to consolidate payment methods to
be a bit more consistent across the
country or is it we're just a little bit
too far beyond the point of return where
the only solution is to basically figure
out how to service the top 10 of those
80 payments.
This is one fortunately where we feel
like the solution is in our hands. So
part of what we do at Carry First is
work with big international uh game
companies to help them monetize in the
region. And so we've built our own
payment system where we aggregate over
120 methods across the region. Um and we
have our own sort of thirdparty web shop
where folks can distribute in-game
content and leverage our payments
backbone to be able to have players be
able to pay for stuff. So, um, that's
one place where we feel like we can
double down and actually solve the
problem, um, without having to wait for
other folks basically. I see. Okay. Um,
and I guess Tammy, any reactions to
that? Maybe from the Xbox perspective,
you know, a place that absolutely is the
merchant of record in a lot of different
places. How are you guys seeing the
presence of Xbox payments in Africa?
Yeah. Um, it's interesting because, you
know, my role, um, primarily I work with
game developers to bring games to Xbox,
but as soon as someone hears I work at
Xbox, they're talking to me about
payments, about how, oh, I can't do this
on the store. I can't like, and I'm
like, guys, I wish I could put you in
touch with who to speak to. Um, so yes,
I would say by far and away it's the
biggest opportunity um, in the industry.
Um, from my point of view, um, like I
said, we've had talks with companies as
well at a Microsoft level. Some of that
is public. We've had talks with
companies like Flutterwave and so on and
so forth. Um, and I think in Nigeria
specifically, if you saw the matrix for
FinTech, financial tech companies in
Nigeria, there's got to be like 600 of
them. It's it's really moving money and
how to move money and efficient ways of
moving money. It's just an endless
opportunity. Um, and it's it's really
interesting because if I was to try and
transfer money to you, I could get it
from my bank to your bank in less than a

that would translate to consumer things
like gaming and Netflix and so on and so
forth. So, I think you know things like
carry first and pay first, I think it's
really smart for people to get ahead of
this but for the creative industries.
So, again like like I said there's 600
of them. So they you need some that are
differentiating and are sort of looking
to serve the market, the gaming market,
the you know the specities of this
market, how people can do um inapp
purchases and so on and so forth. Um so
yes, I think that's that's a that's a
great problem to be solving right now.
Um and from an Xbox point of view, it's
it it would be the key to um unlocking
significant revenue from the console,
more so than
Um, and I guess I I guess you know it's
we talked about this struggles with

genally generally do actually maybe

as someone would in the west but um I

gaming is expensive um and in that

versus, you know, the Asia's pride of
having spent, you know, $3,000 on loot
